title: (x) John Deere logo - (similar to) Trade Gothic Ext {Yves}
content:
[http://www.deere.com/en\_US/deerecom/usa\_canada.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019191508/http:/www.deere.com/en_US/deerecom/usa_canada.html)   
   
Anyone know the typeface used for the logo?
author: sativo

comments.content: I don't know what it is exactly, but [Engravers Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019191508/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/engravers-gothic/engravers-gothic/testdrive.html?s=John%2BDeere&p=60), except for the J, is practically a match.

If you only want the logo you could look [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019191508/http:/web.brandsoftheworld.com/?id=112&query_id=2439086&page=1&brand_id=19495)   
   
I had a quick look at the file in Illustrator, and it appears to be very cleanly drawn, it certainly isn't an auto traced job.

agreeing with Chesh.   
fwiw, Doyald Young was responsible for the previous mark   
and he discussed it on p. 156 of his book, Fonts and Logos.   
(it was modified Franklin Gothic wide).   
   
Here is a small article about Landor's makeover.   
   
 [http://www.corporatelogo.com/articles/171feat1.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019191508/http:/www.corporatelogo.com/articles/171feat1.html)

The John Deere logo was probably based on [Trade Gothic Extended](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019191508/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/trade-gothic/lh-bold-extended/testdrive.html?s=JOHN%20DEERE&p=36).   
All the characters match, but of course you can tell it's adapted because   
of the heavier weight and small caps.
